channel.title: Arrays:
channel.description:
What types of scenarios can they be used in?
I'm learning about them atm and I've known from RSPS programming that it's like this?:
public int moparmods[Chassy13,Newty,Rich];
Or something like that, maybe some more explanation?

item.title: Arrays:
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:27, topic:300457”]here is a faster way

[code]String[] array = null;
if(true) {
array = new String[4];
}
String arrayposition0;
String arrayposition1;
String arrayposition2;
String arrayposition3;
arrayposition0 = “Bobby”;
arrayposition1 = “Kyle”;
arrayposition2 = “Josh”;
arrayposition3 = “Megatron”;

if(arrayposition0.equals(“Bobby”) {
array[0] = arrayposition0;
}
if(arrayposition0.equals(“Kyle”) {
array[1] = arrayposition1;
}
if(arrayposition0.equals(“Josh”) {
array[2] = arrayposition2;
}
if(arrayposition0.equals(“Megatron”) {
array[3] = arrayposition3;
}[/code]

This is the best way to do it, it actually double checks the strings if they are really getting put into the array properly, and if they are correct.[/quote]

Thanks for the code it reduced my lag by tons.

Read full topic

wats so good about that

if(true) { array = new String[4]; } String arrayposition0; String arrayposition1; String arrayposition2; String arrayposition3; arrayposition0 = "Bobby"; arrayposition1 = "Kyle"; arrayposition2 = "Josh"; arrayposition3 = "Megatron";
is their a point to this?[/quote]
i do the checks just to be sure it worked right, sometimes it has not worked right so we make sure. this is the best way to make an array, if anyone uses this idea give me full credits plz

item.title: Arrays:
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

you cant do ‘args = {…}’ because this type of initialization for an array is called an “array initializer” (iirc), which will only work in the initialization that comes along with the declaration of the array

so ‘String[] crap = {…}’ will work but ‘String[] crap; crap = { … }’ will not

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays:
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Just did some testing, weird:

public class Test{ public static void main(String[] args){ args = {"bob", "tom"}; for(String s : args) System.out.println(s); } }
Will not compile.

public class Test{ public static void main(String[] args){ args = new String[]{"bob", "tom"}; for(String s : args) System.out.println(s); } }
Will compile.

public class Test{ public static void main(String[] args){ String[] strr = new String[]{"bob", "tom"}; for(String s : strr) System.out.println(s); } }
Will compile.

public class Test{ public static void main(String[] args){ String[] strr = {"bob", "tom"}; for(String s : strr) System.out.println(s); } }
Will also compile.

So lawl is right. Still it looks like it would be best practice to use the ‘new String[]{…}’ since it works every time.

Read full topic

[/quote]

Almost, instead it would be:

actually, you dont need the new String[] when the “String[] dix =” is there
